ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: foucault's history of sexuality -- power and resistance, the deployment of sexuality as biopower, homosexuality in ancient greece, and the idea that we're all sexually repressed and should be liberated
I definitely gained knowledge about Foucault and the other scholars we read, and the concepts continued to inform my views in other classes.

I learned so much in this course that I definitely will not be able to mention it all, but I learned entire frameworks for considering the world and sexuality that I have applied consistently since learning about them in this class, in addition to context regarding gender and queer theory. Truly a transformative class!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: class had interesting readings, and helpful mini-lectures that break them down and bring greater clarity. breakout room discussions in the beginning are also a good chance to hear other people's thoughts. perhaps there could be a way to encourage more student participation and discussion in the latter half of the class time, although the mini-lectures are certainly not a waste of time.

I think its scope could be broadened somewhat beyond just the History of Sexuality, as it might be easier to grasp HS if taught alongside Foucault's other major works. Overall, though, a solid class with a good base of interesting material.

This class is really interesting--it successfully introduces students to a difficult source material before enabling them to engage deeply in its complex issues. One weakness is that the instructor tends to lecture slightly too much for a seminar format.

Strengths: class discussion, readings

Weaknesses: occasional lagging in pace

Strengths: Professor de Souza is brilliant and extremely kind and helpful, and did a great job engaging with students' thoughts and facilitating debate over the course of the class. We received extremely detailed feedback on our papers, and the readings were also not too immense, with the syllabus being very well designed. Weaknesses: I think I would have appreciated there being more student contribution and discussion after the first half of the class, since after breakout rooms & sharing our thoughts on an initial prompt, we would enter more of a lecture format.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: course was a small seminar and would have been pretty much the same if it were in person, i think.
The class utilized small groups very efficiently

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes. foucault is foundational in queer theory and pops up frequently in other areas, so pretty useful to know his thoughts. this course also provides a nuanced understanding of sexuality, power, and identity that is applicable to many real world cases.
Yes! If you want to truly understand and appreciate the genius of Foucault, please take this class especially with Igor.
I would recommend this course to most people because I feel like the topics we covered can be applied in so many different disciplines.

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student; it is spectacular, not overwhelmingly difficult or high-workload, and I spoke about the things we discussed in the class constantly with my suitemates and friends. The material is incredibly relevant and significant and a phenomenal opportunity to dive into a thinker as influential as Foucault! Take this class!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live virtual lecture and virtual discussion

extras.title:
WGSS 238 01
        Foucault and the Sexual Self
